image.altText: Students sit with their teacher in a classroom

props.synopsis: The federal government will invest an additional $737 million from 2025 to 2029 in Northern Territory public schools under the agreement, which it says will go to addressing serious educational disadvantage in the territory.

title.children: Federal and NT governments announce $1b package to fully fund NT public schools

image.altText: Aerial shot of dozens of houses in neat rows in a new outer-suburban housing estate.

props.synopsis: More than one in four residential properties purchased in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland last year were paid for entirely with cash by older Australians, highlighting the growing disparity in the property market.

title.children: More Australians are buying properties in cash. It risks making the housing affordability divide even worse

image.altText: A photo of Santanaya Namatjira with her tongue out.

props.synopsis: Northern Territory police are calling for information about the whereabouts of a 13-year-old girl who was last seen nearly a week ago walking to a store in Alice Springs.

title.children: Police concerned for Alice Springs girl, 13, missing since last week

image.altText: A portrait photo of a mother surrounded by her three children. There is a suitcase with them. They look close.

props.synopsis: The Top End mother says rural families are leaving the Northern Territory because of the emotional and financial costs of sending children to boarding school.

title.children: Mum says boarding school is a necessity, but it comes at a huge cost for her remote NT family

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Raymond Shaw says he has spent the past five-and-a-half weeks uncovering and exploring disused mine shafts in a determined effort to find anything that helps locate the Ballarat mum.

title.children: There are countless mineshafts in the area being searched for signs of Samantha Murphy. This is what it's like inside them

image.altText: An aerial shot of a large stream of reddish-brown water in an outback landscape.

props.synopsis: Emergency services will this morning attempt to resume searching for a missing party of seven people caught up in WA's flood-stricken outback.

title.children: Search to resume for seven family members missing in severe WA floods

image.altText: A police tape blocks off a suburban street. Police can be seen in the background talking.

props.synopsis: A Darwin court has heard a man was allegedly armed with a spear and attempting to throw it at police officers before one of them fired up to six shots during an altercation in 2022, as dramatic bodyworn video of the incident is aired in court.

title.children: Constable 'feared for his life' during confrontation with man allegedly armed with spear, court hears

image.altText: A woman laying down face up on a beige couch with yellow woolen cardigan, and hands covering her face.

props.synopsis: Coeliac disease can have significant long-term health impacts but most people living with the condition don't know they have it. There are some simple steps to take if you think you're one of them.

title.children: Most people with coeliac disease don't know they have it. Here are the signs to look out for

image.altText: Admiral Jonathan Mead watches a Virginia-class submarine on the water.

props.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles insists AUKUS partners are working "at pace" to help Australia acquire nuclear-powered submarines after the United States revealed it would halve next year's planned production of Virginia-class boats.

title.children: Turnbull says Australians 'mugged by AUKUS reality' as US plans to halve submarine production

image.altText: Two soldiers, with their backs to a camera, operating a large machine outdoors with flames coming out of it

props.synopsis: A former Ukrainian MP urges Australia to provide more support to the country's war effort, after the efficacy of a deal struck with France last year to provide shells to the country's military comes under the microscope.

title.children: One day's worth of shells: Inside Australia's 'slipping' support for Ukraine

image.altText: Andrew Giles scratches his head at a press conference at parliament house

props.synopsis: The federal government has been forced to reveal it bungled issuing visas to 149 people released from immigration detention, meaning some who have breached strict monitoring conditions in the months since may get away with no consequences.

title.children: Immigration bungle could result in former detainees who breached visa conditions escaping conviction

image.altText: A truck dumps a load of tomatoes.

props.synopsis: Fresh produce growers scramble to meet "forecast" supply deals with supermarkets, but every year millions of dollars of surplus food goes to waste. So what's going on?

title.children: Fruit, veg growers say biggest customer 'is the rubbish bin', as millions of tonnes of food is wasted

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses with her hair tied back sits in a chair in a tv studio.

props.synopsis: Former Liberal MP Bronwyn Bishop apologises to Sophie Scamps after calling her "anti-Semitic" for asking for funding to be restored to the United Nations aid agency operating in Gaza.

title.children: Bronwyn Bishop makes on-air apology to Sophie Scamps for calling her 'anti-Semitic'

image.altText: An aerial view of hundreds of tents set up on brown sand across a stretch of land with a blue sky in the distance.

props.synopsis: The UK foreign secretary was questioned about the a BBC report of Palestinian medics recounting alleged abuse and detention by Israeli troops following a hospital raid.

title.children: 'Very disturbing': David Cameron calls for answers to report of Israeli troops abusing Palestinian medics

image.altText: The drug ice sitting on a bench top.

props.synopsis: Australia's alcohol consumption is in decline while the use of other drugs such as methamphetamines, cocaine and MDMA is growing, according to new wastewater analysis.

title.children: Australia's criminal intelligence agency tested our sewage for drugs. This is what they found

image.altText: Sun in an orange sky overlooking a wharf

props.synopsis: After a hot and humid summer, NSW is now enduring an extended spell of warm autumn weather moving into its second week.

title.children: Sydney's waters now warm enough for a tropical cyclone

image.altText: Reds players recover in the heat during

props.synopsis: After a weekend where extreme heat delayed major league games, there is no question anymore about the impact climate change has on sport. But a new report by an organisation of athletes has found most major sporting bodies have so far stayed silent on the issue.

title.children: The sports we love face a massive threat, and some of the big Aussie codes don't have a game plan

image.altText: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang dressed in suits stand inside a room.

props.synopsis: As China's annual rubberstamp parliament comes to a close, there are still looming questions about whether policymakers are doing enough to tackle the country's economic malaise, writes Kathleen Calderwood.

title.children: 'Not good': Beijing insists everything is fine. Here's what real people say about China's economic situation

image.altText: A man and a woman looking serious standing next to a wall

props.synopsis: Their home was supposed to be Kim and Keven's retirement dream, but they say the build was riddled with issues, significantly delayed, and they kept hitting walls trying to get problems fixed.

title.children: From a leaking bathroom to safety hazards, couple fights to have issues fixed in $1m newly built dream retirement home

image.altText: A white van carrying Armaguard's badge logo stationary in a parking lot.

props.synopsis: The big four banks are poised to intervene in the business of transporting cash because its plummeting use is making it unprofitable for Armaguard to deliver.

title.children: Declining cash use threatening nation's money mover Armaguard

image.altText: A statue of a bull charging sits on a paved city street

props.synopsis: The three key US indices jump even though inflation data raises more questions about the timing of future cuts to interest rates in the world's largest economy. Follow on our live markets blog.

title.children: Wall St jumps despite hotter-than-expected inflation reading

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX set to lift after Wall Street rises with inflation news

image.altText: Godzilla stalks a boat from behind while they are both in the sea

props.synopsis: On a budget of $18–23 million dollars, Godzilla Minus One has redefined what a low-budget action film can achieve — and it has the Oscar to prove it.

title.children: What Godzilla Minus One's Oscar win means for the movie industry

image.altText: Individual pictures of five teenagers' faces on a colourful background with a sign reading "uni options" and picture of a plane.

props.synopsis: From creating a national "jobs broker" to raising income support, potential changes could open a world of educational possibilities for rural students.

title.children: Will university reforms help more young people chase their dreams?

image.altText: Two people looking at a smartphone, a younger person pointing out the screen to an elderly woman

props.synopsis: There are promising signs a crackdown is working, however Australians were fleeced of just under half a billion dollars last year, according to new ACCC Scamwatch figures.

title.children: Fake ads on the rise as scams on social media claim more older victims

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: It comes after a judicial review found communications between a journalist and the head of the inquiry, Walter Sofronoff, could lead a fair-minded observer to conclude the reporter impacted Mr Sofronoff's views.

title.children: Former ACT top prosecutor wants the government to redact parts of the report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Three soldiers operate a missile launcher in light scrub

props.synopsis: Armed fighters who say they are Russian claim to have crossed the border from Ukraine to attack targets on the same day a wave of drone attacks damaged energy facilities including an oil refinery.

title.children: Anti-Kremlin fighters say they've taken a Russian village after cross-border attack from Ukraine

image.altText: A koala with bandaged paws sits in the crook of a tree branch within a recovery facility

props.synopsis: Climate change and bushfires are forcing massive changes to the way Australia conserves threatened animals and plants.

title.children: How the plan to manage threatened species has evolved since Black Summer

image.altText: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration.

props.synopsis: Artificial intelligence skills are increasingly in demand, with the number of job ads requiring AI skills surging 21-fold in the past year. LinkedIn's chief economist reveals which jobs are likely to be disrupted by AI — for better or worse.

title.children: Rise of artificial intelligence could cut wages of workers who don't 'upskill' as AI job ads surge

image.altText: Terry Antonis smiles during A-League Men match

props.synopsis: From just inside the halfway line, Melbourne City's Terry Antonis scores one of the best goals seen in the A-League Men, as Western Sydney Wanderers fall to their heaviest defeat in the competition.

title.children: 'Never seen anything like that': Antonis's breathtaking goal helps Melbourne City thump Wanderers 7-0

image.altText: Man, woman and child kneeling on ground with man holding up a large python.

props.synopsis: What precautions can you take to make your property as unappealing to snakes as possible — and what should you do if you do spot one? We ask the experts.

title.children: What you should and shouldn't do if you see or hear a snake in your home or yard

image.altText: A red and white ship cutting through a body of icy water.

props.synopsis: An internal government document obtained by the ABC says there is an "emerging prospect" of the US Coast Guard basing one of its vessels in Hobart — but US and Australian officials are remaining tight-lipped.

title.children: Officials tight-lipped over 'emerging prospect' of US Coast Guard using Hobart as a home port
